metadata.title: Low-Temperature Synthesis of Thermoresponsive Diblock Copolymer Nano-Objects via Aqueous Photoinitiated Polymerization-Induced Self- Assembly (Photo-PISA) using Thermoresponsive Macro-RAFT Agents

sections.text:
Communication Macromolecular Rapid Communications
wileyonlinelibrary.com 1© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim DOI: 10.1002/marc.201600299
morphologies and has been one of the major interests in polymer science.[8] Amphiphilic diblock copolymers spontaneously undergo self-assembly in water to form various diblock copolymer nano-objects, such as spheres, worms, and vesicles. However, traditional self-assembly methods are invariably conducted in dilute aqueous solutions (<1%) and sometimes require post-polymerization processing using a solvent or pH switch, which is difficult to implement on a large scale.[9–12]
In the past six years, several research groups have reported that polymerization-induced self-assembly (PISA) can be achieved using either aqueous dispersion polymerization or aqueous emulsion polymerization based on reversible addition-fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT) polymerization.[13,14] This approach enables the synthesis of diblock copolymer nano-objects with various morphologies in water at high solids contents (10–30%), which is particularly appealing for the preparation of
Photoinitiated reversible addition-fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT) dispersion polymerization of 2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate is conducted in water at low temperature using thermoresponsive copolymers of 2-(2-methoxyethoxy) ethyl methacrylate and oligo(ethylene glycol) methacrylate (Mn = 475 g mol−1) as the macro-RAFT agent. Kinetic studies confirm that quantitative monomer conversion is achieved within 15 min of visiblelight irradiation (405 nm, 0.5 mW cm−2), and good control is maintained during the polymerization. The polymerization can be temporally controlled by a simple “ON/OFF” switch of the light source. Finally, thermoresponsive diblock copolymer nano-objects with a diverse set of complex morphologies (spheres, worms, and vesicles) are prepared using this particular formulation.

sections.heading: Jianbo Tan,* Yuhao Bai, Xuechao Zhang, Chundong Huang, Dongdong Liu,
Li Zhang*
sections.text: Prof. J. Tan, Y. Bai, X. Zhang, C. Huang, D. Liu, Prof. L. Zhang Department of Polymeric Materials and Engineering School of Materials and Energy Guangdong University of Technology Guangzhou 510006, China E-mail: tanjianbo@gdut.edu.cn; lizhang@gdut.edu.cn Prof. J. Tan, Prof. L. Zhang Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Functional Soft Condensed Matter Guangzhou 510006, China

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Thermoresponsive polymer nano-objects have attracted much attention due to their broad applications in hydrogels, drug delivery, bioseparation, Pickering emulsions, and 3D cell culture.[1–7] Self-assembly is a commonly used strategy to prepare polymer nano-objects with different
Early View Publication; these are NOT the final page numbers, use DOI for citation !!
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201600299
www.MaterialsViews.com2 © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
biorelated materials. There are several reports describing thermoresponsive diblock copolymer nano-objects prepared via aqueous PISA. An et al.[15] reported a RAFT-mediated precipitation polymerization of N-isopropylacrylamide (NIPAM) using two types of macro-RAFT agents. The obtained polymeric nanoparticles exhibited thermoresponsive behaviors by changing the solution temperature. Blanazs et al.[16] reported the synthesis of poly(glycerol monomethacrylate)-poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate) (PGMA-PHPMA) worms via aqueous RAFT dispersion polymerization, and a worm-to-sphere transition was observed by changing the temperature from 25 to 4 °C. Sumerlin and co-workers[17] developed a polymerizationinduced thermal self-assembly of NIPAM to achieve a wide range of polymeric nanoparticles morphologies. In order to characterize the obtained polymer nano-objects at ambient temperature, they further crosslinked the corona prior to transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterization. Shen et al.[18] reported the preparation of crosslinked core–shell nanoparticles with a thermoresponsive core by aqueous RAFT dispersion polymerization of 2-methoxyethyl acrylate, poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) methyl ether acrylate, and PEG diacrylate. Increasing the solution temperature from 20 to 60 °C led to a significant decrease in particle diameter.
However, the preparation of thermoresponsive diblock copolymer nano-objects via aqueous PISA using a thermoresponsive stabilizer block is rare. This may be ascribed to the high reaction temperature required for most aqueous PISA formulations (usually 70 °C), which will lead to the precipitation of thermoresponsive polymers in water. To address this problem, Kessel et al.[19] developed a RAFTmediated emulsion polymerization conducted at 70 °C by using a PNIPAM macro-RAFT agent, and additional surfactants were used as the stabilizer to ensure the stability of the target particles. More recently, Truong et al.[20] reported a similar strategy to prepare either polystyrene or polymethacrylate nano-objects using a poly((di(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate)-coN-(2-hydroxypropyl) methacrylamide) macro-RAFT agent as the steric stabilizer. It should be noted that the use of surfactant limits the application in certain areas, such as coating and drug delivery. Moreover, the addition of toluene or hydrophobic monomer was required to plasticize the hydrophobic core. Strictly speaking, this is not an example of conventional PISA since the thermoresponsive macro-RAFT agent was not able to act as a steric stabilizer in water at 70 °C. Further temperature-induced morphological transformation was required to achieve higher order morphologies.
Photoinitiated living radical polymerization has been widely used in polymer synthesis and materials preparation due to its ambient reaction conditions and temporally controlled ability.[21] Recently, there has been
interest by several groups in developing photoinitiated PISA, especially visible-light-mediated PISA. For example, Boyer and co-workers[22] reported a visible-light-mediated PISA formulation of benzyl methacrylate (BzMA) in alcoholic media using Ru(bpy)3Cl2 as the photoredox catalysis and various morphologies (spheres, worms, and vesicles) could be obtained. The same group[23] also reported a visible-light-mediated PISA formulation in the absence of external catalyst or initiator. They found that wormlike nano-objects could be readily achieved by observing the viscosity of the reaction mixture. Yu et al.[24] reported the use of polyion complexation for aqueous PISA via the exposure to visible light, and spherical micelles were formed. Recently, our group developed a photoinitiated RAFT dispersion polymerization of HPMA in water, and a diverse set of diblock copolymer nano-objects were obtained according to a photoinitiated PISA (photo-PISA) mechanism.[25] The photo-PISA can be carried out at room temperature or lower, a feature that is particular appealing for the synthesis of thermoresponsive diblock copolymer nano-objects without any additional surfactant. Herein, we report a photo-PISA formulation via aqueous RAFT dispersion polymerization at low temperatures to prepare thermoresponsive diblock copolymer nano-objects using thermoresponsive macro-RAFT agents as the stabilizer. The low reaction temperature is critical in this case to ensure that the thermoresponsive macroRAFT agents are soluble in the reaction mixture.

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Thermoresponsive macro-RAFT agents were prepared via RAFT solution copolymerization of 2-(2-methoxyethoxy) ethyl methacrylate (MEO2MA) and oligo(ethylene glycol) methacrylate (OEGMA) (Mn = 475 g mol−1) in 1,4-dioxane at 70 °C using 2,2-azobisisobutyronitrile as the initiator and 4-cyano-4-(dodecylsulfanylthiocarbonyl) sulfanylpentan oic acid (CDPA) as the RAFT agent. Lutz et al.[26] reported that the lower critical solution temperature (LCST) of P(MEO2MA-co-OEGMA) in water could be varied from 20 to 90 °C by changing the molar ratio between MEO2MA and OEGMA. In the present study, three P(MEO2MA-co-OEGMA) macro-RAFT agents were prepared (P(MEO2MA26.8-coOEGMA1.4)-CDPA, P(MEO2MA24.2-co-OEGMA2.7)-CDPA, and P(MEO2MA23.4-co-OEGMA5.8)-CDPA)). The obtained macroRAFT agents were then employed as steric stabilizers and sodium phenyl-2,4,6-trimethylbenzoylphosphinate (SPTP) was chosen as the photoinitiator in aqueous photoPISA of HPMA via the exposure to visible light (405 nm, 0.5 mW cm−2) as shown in Scheme 1.
To act as a steric stabilizer in aqueous PISA, the macroRAFT agent must be soluble in water. Initial aqueous photo-PISA experiments were carried out at 20 °C
Early View Publication; these are NOT the final page numbers, use DOI for citation !!
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201600299
www.MaterialsViews.com 3© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
with 10% w/w HPMA. However, we found that macroRAFT agents could not dissolve in the reaction mixture (Figure S1, Supporting Information). This phenomenon may be attributed to the strong interaction of HPMA with P(MEO 2 MA- co -OEGMA)-CDPA in water at this temperature. Similar thermoresponsive behaviors have also been reported in the case of PNIPAM in mixed solvents of water/alcohol. [ 27,28 ] The LCSTs of P(MEO 2 MA- co -OEGMA)CDPA in water and 10% w/w HPMA aqueous solution were measured by transmittance as shown in Figure 1 . It
can be clearly seen that the presence of 10% w/w HPMA leads to a signifi cant decrease of LCSTs in water, and difference in LCST as high as 29 °C was observed in the case of P(MEO 2 MA 23.4 - co -OEGMA 5.8 )-CDPA.
Fortunately, photoinitiated polymerization is a technique that can be carried out at low temperatures. [ 24,29–31 ] To prove the versatility of aqueous photo-PISA at low temperatures, kinetic studies were conducted using POEGMA 15 -CDPA as the macro-RAFT agent with 10 wt% HPMA in water at either 4, 10, or 20 °C and monitored by
Early View Publication; these are NOT the final page numbers, use DOI for citation !!
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201600299
Scheme 1 . Synthesis of poly(2-(2-methoxyethoxy) ethyl methacrylate- co -oligo(ethylene glycol) methacrylate)-b-poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate) diblock copolymer nano-objects via photoinitiated RAFT dispersion polymerization in water.
www.MaterialsViews.com4 © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
1 H NMR spectroscopy, as shown in Figure 2 a. It should be noted that POEGMA 15 -CDPA chosen here is based on its relatively high LCST (around 40 °C) in 10% w/w HPMA aqueous solution (see Figure S2, Supporting Information). These results indicate that aqueous photo-PISA can be carried out at low temperatures with a high rate of polymerization. It should be noted that high monomer conversion (>96%) was achieved at 20 °C, while around 90% monomer conversion was achieved at either 10 °C or 4 °C. This may be attributed to the higher solubility of HPMA in water at lower temperature, [ 32 ] resulting in a lower local concentration of HPMA in the micelle cores, and this in turn leads to lower rate of polymerization. Moreover, the rapid decomposition of SPTP under 405 nm irradiation may lead to insuffi cient radical fl ux after 30 min, and thus resulting in incomplete monomer conversions. As a proof of concept, P(MEO 2 MA 23.4 - co -OEGMA 5.8 )-CDPA with a LCST of 49.5 °C was employed as a steric stabilizer in aqueous photo-PISA of HPMA to prepare thermoresponsive diblock copolymer nano-objects under 405 nm light irradiation.
A kinetic plot for the aqueous photo-PISA of HPMA (Figure 2 b, target degree of polymerization (DP) of 200) at 10 wt% HPMA concentration and at 15 °C using P(MEO 2 MA 23.4 - co -OEGMA 5.8 )-CDPA was obtained by withdrawing samples at different time intervals. The poly merization proceeded rapidly with quantitative monomer conversion being reached with 15 min of
visible-light irradiation. The semilogarithmic plot in the inset of Figure 2 b shows two regimes. The fi rst regime is from 0 to 9 min, which corresponds to the homogeneous polymerization. In the second regime, the rate of polymerization increases by a factor of 2 after 9 min; this corresponds to the onset of nucleation. Interpolation of the lines indicates that the nucleation occurred at 9 min, which corresponds to a monomer conversion of 69% for this particular photo-PISA formulation. At this point, unreacted HPMA monomer enters the nuclei to solvate the hydrophobic PHPMA chains, which leads to a high local monomer concentration and hence the observed rate enhancement. Aliquots extracted during the kinetic study were also analyzed by gel-permeation chromatography (GPC), which confi rmed the linear evolution of M n with monomer conversion (Figure 2 c). These characteristics are typical for a pseudo-living radical polymerization. The corresponding GPC traces are also shown in Figure 2 d. Unimodal GPC curves are observed during the nucleation stage (0 to 9 min), while GPC curves with a shoulder on the left were observed during the particle growth stage (9 to 20 min). This may be attributed to unexpected bimolecular termination under photo-PISA conditions.
It is well known that photoinduced “living”/controlled radical polymerization can be activated or deactivated by light. [ 22,33–35 ] To examine whether the present photo-PISA formulation can be temporally controlled, we exposed
Early View Publication; these are NOT the final page numbers, use DOI for citation !!
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201600299
www.MaterialsViews.com 5© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
the reaction mixture to alternating “ON/OFF” cycles of external light stimulation. Aliquots were withdrawn at different times and immediately analyzed by 1 H NMR spectrometry and GPC. Figure 3 a indicates that when the external visible-light source was OFF, no polymerization occurred during this period; in contrast, when the external visible-light source was ON, the polymerization proceeded as expected. Figure 3 b shows the linear evolution of M n with monomer conversion, suggesting that pseudo-living radical polymerization was maintained despite the intermittent turning on and off of the light source. The “ON/OFF” property of photo-PISA may enable the development of novel PISA formulations, since one can stop the polymerization by just turning off the light source and reactivated again by turning on the light source.
One of the main advantages of PISA is its ability to prepare higher order morphologies (e.g., worms, vesicles)
by changing reaction parameters. Herein, a series of P(MEO 2 MA 23.4 - co -OEGMA 5.8 )- b -PHPMA n ( n = 100, 200, 300) were prepared by aqueous photo-PISA of HPMA at 15 °C with 10% w/w or 20% w/w HPMA. At 10% w/w HPMA concentration, the in situ self-assembly of P(MEO 2 MA 23.4 - co -OEGMA 5.8 )- b -PHPMA 100 copolymer resulted in the formation of spherical nanoparticles, as shown in Figure 3 c. Increasing the target DP of the PHPMA block to 200 and 300, pure vesicular morphologies were obtained in both case (see Figure 3 d,e). At 20% w/w HPMA concentration, pure worms were obtained when the target DP of the PHPMA block was 100 as shown in Figure 3 f. The dispersion formed a soft transparent gel, which can be attributed to inter-worm entanglements, a feature that has proven to be common in PISA. [ 16,36 ] We then examined the thermoresponsive property of the P(MEO 2 MA 23.4 - co -OEGMA 5.8 )- b -PHPMA 100 nanoparticles (prepared at 10% w/w HPMA concentration, Figure 3 c) in water by
Early View Publication; these are NOT the final page numbers, use DOI for citation !!
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201600299
www.MaterialsViews.com6 © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Early View Publication; these are NOT the final page numbers, use DOI for citation !!
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201600299
transmittance. As shown in Figure 3g, the transmittance starts to decrease at 36 °C with a middle point at 42 °C, and leveled off at 50 °C. It can be clearly seen that the thermoresponsive transition of the P(MEO2MA23.4-coOEGMA5.8)-b-PHPMA100 nanoparticles takes place within a broad temperature range (14 °C in this case) compared to P(MEO2MA23.4-co-OEGMA5.8)-CDPA. This can be explained by the steric repulsion among the crowded stabilizer chains tethered on the PHPMA core, which retards the soluble-to-insoluble transition of the P(MEO2MA23.4co-OEGMA5.8) chains.[37] Dynamic light scattering measurement confirmed that the P(MEO2MA23.4-co-OEGMA5.8)b-PHPMA100 nanoparticles were stable at different temperatures (see Figure S7, Supporting Information).
We then attempted to synthesize thermoresponsive diblock copolymer nano-objects via aqueous photoPISA of HPMA using P(MEO2MA26.8-co-OEGMA1.4)-CDPA (LCST = 25.5 °C). Polymerizations were carried out at 4 °C, and around 90% monomer conversions were achieved in all studied cases. Samples were extracted at 4 °C, diluted with water at the same temperature, stained with uranyl acetate, and imaged by TEM. However, no vesicles but spheres and branched worms could be observed in this case even the target DP of PHPMA increased to 270, as shown in Figure S3 (Supporting Information). This may be ascribed to the thermoresponsive property of PHPMA block at low temperatures. For example, Mable et al.[38] reported that PHPMA-based vesicles (prepared using a nonthermoresponsive stabilizer block) underwent a morphology change to form a mixture of spheres and worms on cooling to a temperature lower than 10 °C. We are currently working on the development of novel aqueous photo-PISA formulations that can prepare thermoresponsive polymer vesicles with low LCSTs.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In conclusion, this work demonstrates that the LCSTs of P(MEO2MA-co-OEGMA) polymers in water decreased significantly with the addition of HPMA. Aqueous photoPISA of HPMA was conducted at low temperatures using thermoresponsive macro-RAFT agents. Kinetic studies confirmed that quantitative monomer conversion was achieved within 15 min of visible-light irradiation, and GPC analysis indicated well-controlled radical polymerization. The polymerization can be temporally controlled by a simple “ON/OFF” switch of the light source. The typical range of nano-object morphologies (spheres, worms, and vesicles) were prepared by photo-PISA at 15 °C using a thermoresponsive macro-RAFT agent with a LCST of 49.5 °C. The thermoresponsive transition of the obtained nanoparticles takes place within a broad temperature range compared to the macro-RAFT agent.

Supporting Information is available from the Wiley Online Library or from the author.

Low-Temperature Synthesis of Thermoresponsive Diblock Copolymer Nano-Objects via Aqueous Photoinitiated Polymerization-Induced SelfAssembly (Photo-PISA) using Thermoresponsive Macro-RAFT Agents
